Message.Title: Time running out for Sec. of Defense repacement for Hagel
Message.Msg: The hunt for a former Los Angeles police officer suspected in three killings entered a fourth day in snow-covered mountains Sunday. The Obama Administration is frantically appealing to Christopher Dorner, the top choice for Secretary of Defense behind Chuck Hagel, to turn himself in to authorities. By way of Presidential executive order, Dorner will be pardoned for his crimes and ready for confirmation hearings next Thursday. Ambassador Susan Rice is to hit the Sunday morning media shows explaining why Dorner should be appointed Secretary of Defense due to the severe racial injustice inflicted upon him.

Message.Title: Three Ill Democrats
Message.Msg: Three desperately ill Democrats and specimen here at the Institute, met with the MSI doctor one day to discuss their options. One was an alcoholic, Carolyn; one was a chain-smoker, Farragut and one was a homosexual, Starkdirty. The doctor, addressing all three of them, said, "If any of you indulge in your vices one more time, you will surely die." The MSI specimen left the doctor's office, each convinced that they would never again indulge in their vice. While walking toward the subway for their return trip to the suburbs, they passed a bar. Carolyn, the alcoholic, hearing the loud music and smelling the ale, could not stop herself. Her buddies accompanied her into the Bar, where he had a shot of whiskey. No sooner had she replaced the shot glass on the bar, she fell off his stool, stone cold dead. Her companions, somewhat shaken, left the bar, realizing how seriously they must take the doctor's words. As they walked along, they came upon a cigarette butt lying on the ground, still burning. Starkdirty, the homosexual looked at Farragut, the chain-smoker and said, "You know if you bend over to pick that up, we're both dead."

Message.Title: Many 2011 federal budget cuts had little real-world effect
Message.Msg: From the Wash Post................But the bill also turned out to be an epic kind of Washington illusion. It was stuffed with gimmicks that made the cuts seem far bigger — and the politicians far bolder — than they actually were. In the real world, in fact, many of their “cuts” cut nothing at all. The Transportation Department got credit for “cutting” a $280 million tunnel that had been canceled six months earlier. It also “cut” a $375,000 road project that had been created by a legislative typo, on a road that did not exist. At the Census Bureau, officials got credit for a whopping $6 billion cut, simply for obeying the calendar. They promised not to hold the expensive 2010 census again in 2011.

Message.Title: BAC DIVIDENT DATES
Message.Msg: Does anyone know when is the ''next'' BAC dividend date, Dividend Record Date: ? Dividend Pay Date: ? Thank you.

Topic.Title: BAC DIVIDENT DATES

Message.Msg: CHARLOTTE, N.C.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Jan. 23, 2013-- Bank of America Corporation today announced the Board of Directors declared a regular quarterly cash dividend on Bank of America common stock of $0.01 per share, payable on March 22, 2013 to shareholders of record as of March 1, 2013. The board also declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $1.75 per share on the 7 percent Cumulative Redeemable Preferred Stock, Series B. The dividend is payable on April 25, 2013 to shareholders of record as of April 11, 2013.

Message.Title: no transparency with the green industry's toxic waste
Message.Msg: "The Silicon Valley Toxics Coalition, a watchdog group created in 1982 in response to severe environmental problems associated with the valley's electronics industry, is now trying to keep the solar industry from making similar mistakes through a voluntary waste reporting "scorecard." So far, only 14 of 114 companies contacted have replied. Those 14 were larger firms that comprised 51-percent of the solar market share. "We find the overall industry response rate to our request for environmental information to be pretty dismal for an industry that is considered 'green,'" the group's executive director, Sheila Davis, said in an email. While there are no specific industry standards, Smirnow, head of the solar industry association, is spearheading a voluntary program of environmental responsibility. So far, only seven of the group's nearly 81 manufacturers have signed the pledge. "We want (our program) to be more demanding, but this is a young industry and right now manufacturing companies are focused on survival," he said."
